column4: Hi everyone. Why does my headless Ubuntu 12.04 stays on resolution of 800*600? I can't change it anywhere. I even tried different resolution values in my VNC client/server but with no luck!
what vncserver are you using?
The standard vino-server. I tried x11vnc but with no luck either.
if its headless theres no need to 'share the current visible desktop' thats how vino and x11vncserver work.. use a normal vnc server like 'tightvnc'
I will give tightvnc a go. Thanks.
vnc does not need to share the current visible desktop on linux. ;) unlike how it works on windows. You can have a dozen vnc 'hidden' desktops you connect to with just vnc clients.
There seems to be only Windows version of tighvnc. The other one is Java based! Which one do you use? Is installation straight forward?
the tightvnc server is in the repos.
vnc servers often have a java 'feature' where you can connect to them from a web browser.
Gotchya. Downloading it now from the repo :)
if the server is on the same local lan, you may want to check out the xdmcp/x forwareding features of SSH instead of running a whole vnc session.
I'm fairly new to Linux so I can't really understand what you just mentioned above lol..
How do I start tightvncserver, and how can I configure it? Where is the config file located at?
differnt ways to  have remote apps.. if you have more then 1 linux/ubuntu machine on the lan. learning ssh is worth the time.
run vncserver, then it puts files in .vnc you can alter .  check its docs/man pages also.   basically you run it. it gives the desktop #, you connect with a client.
is this over the internet? or a local lan?
LAN
what is the OS of the other machiunes on the lan?
there may be ways to do X forwarding to the MAC that would let you run single apps and have them appear locally on the mac.
I get this error message when I start the server "Please set correct fontPath in the tightvncserver script."
Do you know where I can find the config file? the 'man' command doesn't really show where it is.
in the users .vnc directory
Is it the .log or .pid file?
